text: LSAT Freedom Trip #159. Keg at the brewpub. Clear dark ruby, large foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of toffee, caramel, jammy orange, dried apricot. The taste is toffee, toasted malt, dark fruit. Medium bodied.

Pours dark brown, almost black with a thick off-white head. Aroma of malt and dark fruit with a touch of toffee. Taste follows, smooth chocolate, toffee and caramel with a touch of bitterness. Light yet flavorful

At the brewpub: Pours dark blackish brown with a tan head. Aroma is earthy chocolate, light hops. Taste is simple, but really nice. Hoppiness is heavier than one would expect in an English iteration of the style. The sweetness is also very muted. Nice and earthy taste. Bittersweet chocolate is certainly present. Low carbonation body is really pleasant. If I was a British coal miner from the 19th century, I would be really jealous.

[ Cask ][ 5oz ][ @F&M ][ $2 ][ mini-pint ][ 9/13/14 ]Hazy amber, puffy cream head craters but doesnt die. Dusty wood nose, light almond and orange with an earthy grass bitterness balance. Melon rind and orange early, papery bitterness alongside more caramel and orange mid. The earthy nut accents growing alongside low acidity and ultra-high attenuation thats light and coating through the finish. Thin body, cask low-carb, needing juicier elements and slightly bloated full feeling. All that said, this is very strong, excellent attenuation and balance.
Hand pump. Brown pour with tan head. Roasted and dry malty aromas. Chocolate and roasted flavors. Solid mild? Or porter?
Draft at brewpub. Pours dark brown with khaki head. Nose is earthy, malty, brown sugary. Tastes vienna malty, smooth, with earthy and hop notes.

On cask at the brewpub. At this point, Im beginning to think that these guys can do Session beer like nobody else, wrapping experience in crafting tradition with a few tweaks. This was good and had a nicely nutty edge to it, but wasnt overly complex and showed its light weight more than the Golden Eternity. Some almond-like creaminess, toothy molasses, and tight sugar. Delicious, but less captivating.
On tap at the F&M Brew Pub. Poured a brownish color with an off white head. Chocolate, some roast, caramel, and some floral hops.

Cask flight at the brewpub. Dark amber color, nearly brown with red hues.  Moderately well laced off white head. Faint English malt and hop aroma.  Taste is thin but with a decent hop bitterness that lingers in the mouth. Malts are subtle and slightly sweet. Thin but oily mouthfeel.
On tap at FM with mike.  Soda like look  little head.  On cask..  mild flavor roast and malt body thinner

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2013 Dark brown body (not black), medium off-white head, decent lacing.  Nose is highlighted by mellow chocolate and hints of caramel, toffee, and nuttiness.  Flavor has all of the pop of a chocolate stout with minimal roast--pleasant complementary notes of caramel, toffee, and bread. Light (very light) floral hop notes. Medium bodied, low carbonation from the cask, malty, without any real residual sweetness, lightly bitter.  Clean flavors.

Draft at brewpub. Pours a coca cola brown with lots of nice white head. Aroma is faint, but shows some chocolate and slight roasty flavors.Taste is a lot more intense than youd expect for its ABV. Smooth chocolate notes with the faintest coffee notes mix with a very smooth palate. Really easy to drink on hand pump. Nice to see a mild ale at a brewpub too.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2012 [Cask] Reddish brown color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of light diactyl, cocoa, light roast, nuts, and caramel malts.  Taste of the same, cocoa, caramel, and light roast, with a semi-sweet finish.
